Mary Louvi is 36, married, and has two children aged three and two. She is engaged in farming and has been growing rice for some time now. Her husband is the one who mainly manages their rice farm. She makes sure to support him in keeping their rice farm productive. 

Mary Louvi also manages their sari-sari (variety) store business. The store has been running for two years now. Mary Louvi sells items like sugar, vinegar, and cooking oil. 

Mary Louvi requested a loan to purchase seed, fertilizer, and other farm inputs. She is hopeful that this loan will help them achieve a good harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seed, fertilizer, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane lives in Uganda. She is married and has seven children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).

Jane has a mini-bakery. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week. Jane sells her products at retail in the market.

She has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more cartons of baking flour, cow peas, and cooking oil.

The main business challenges for Jane include seasonality, the ever-increasing price of cooking oil, and theft. Her goals for her business are to own a fully stocked bakery. Jane lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and medication.

loans.use: to buy cartons of baking flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Pon's Group

texts.en:
From villagers who live in Siem Reap Province, five low-income people have decided to seek a loan for different purposes. One of these people, Mr. Pon, 31, has been chosen as the leader of this loan group by the other members. Mr. Pon currently works as a porter in his community. He gets an income his job of about $3 a day to manage his family’s needs. He is married with two teenage children who are still unemployed. His wife sells a few items next to the village. Mr. Pon’s wife is now out of inventory in her store and she wants to resupply with extra-goods to continue on selling. That is why Mr. Pon is applying for a loan to assists his wife’s business with additional capital to buy more items to sell.  

The other four borrowers are: 
Mr. Bech, a porter, who is asking for a loan to mend his house, which is broken down. 
Mr. Soeurn is a porter and fish catcher, who will be using the loan money to purchase nets for fishing.
Mr. Khem is a fisherman, who is requesting a loan to buy a new boat to replace his old one.
Mr. Yorn is also a domestic porter, who is seeking a loan to repair his old house.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie, a 56-year-old widowed mother of six, works hard to support her children by growing rice to sell in Banga, South Cotabato.  She also sells dried fish to the people in her community. Rosemarie is now requesting a loan to purchase three sacks of seeds, two sacks of fertilizers, and two quarts of herbicides. She hopes to have a successful business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 3 sacks of seeds, 2 sacks of fertilizers and 2 quarts of herbicides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits to sell.

loans.name: Katagata Farmers Group

texts.en: Eldard, a married father of nine children, has been selling cattle for 10 years in Bushenyi, enabling him, through hard work, to earn about 100,000 shillings per week. He also derives extra income selling bananas grown on a plantation he owns. With the Kiva loan, Eldard plans to buy more cattle for resale, and in the future expects to expand his business in order to raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more cattle for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
From Uganda, Rose is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. She rents her home and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

For five years Rose has sold Cavendish bananas. She sells her bananas at the market seven days a week. The main business challenges for Rose include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of Cavendish bananas due to drought and famine which has hit Uganda.

Rose has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of Cavendish bananas. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale prices only and to educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of Cavendish bananas.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles has a mixed farm in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya that produces bananas, coffee, tomatoes and French beans. He has been in the farming business for 20 years, selling all his produce at the local market. Farming has been his main source of income. His major challenge has been lack of a ready market for farm produce, which affects his cash flows. 

Charles has requested a loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings in order to cultivate his banana farm. He specifically wants to expand the acreage under bananas by acquiring more land. He says that this will improve his banana production and enable him to enjoy the economies of scale. The proceeds from this loan will enable him to improve his family's livelihood. In the future, he plans to acquire a piece of land in order to build a modern house for his family.

Charles is 54 and married with eight children. Six of his children are currently attending school.

loans.use: To expand his banana farm by acquiring more land.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
At the age of 23, Analyn is married and has three children. Her husband is a rice farmer while she is planning to start raising pigs to generate more income. She is asking for a loan amount of 10,000 PHP to buy piglets and feed.

Analyn hopes that with this loan she will grow her business so as to support the studies of her children in the coming years. If she manages it well, then it will eventually help her to elevate her family from poverty.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to install and offer DStv (digital satellite TV) from his video business.

loans.name: Mahoutin-Lobozounkpa Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHOUTIN-LOBOZOUNKPA est composé de trois personnes,  qui vivent toutes dans la même maison. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Ambroisine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Ambroisine est âgée de 31 ans et vit au Bénin. Ambroisine est mariée à un maçon du nom de Théodore. Le couple a deux  enfants tous scolarisés set ne vivant plus avec eux. Ambroisine a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Pour assurer convenablement le rôle de mère de famille, Ambroisine mène comme activité la vente des mèches, des sachets et des produits cosmétiques. A côté de cette activité, Ambroisine vend des articles de merceries. Ambroisine mène cette activité depuis un an. Ambroisine achète ses produits au Togo et aussi au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d'affaires et son revenu, Ambroisine sollicite un second crédit, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHOUTIN-LOBOZOUNKPA.
texts.en: The Mahoutin-Lobozounkpa group comprises three people who all live in the same house. This is the second time this group is seeking financial support from ALIDÉ in order to to raise the level of this businesses. The group representative, named Ambroisine, is the one whose hand is raised in the photo. Ambroisine is 31 years old and lives in Benin. She is married to a mason named Théodore. The couple have two children, both in school, and neither of whom live with their parents. Ambroisine attended school up to the secondary level. To properly fulfill the role of mother of the family, Ambroisine runs a business selling hair extensions, bags, and cosmetics. Along with this activity, she also sells haberdashery items. She has run this business for a year and buys her supplies in Togo and also in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her clientele and increasing her sales and income, she is seeking a second loan together with the other members of the Mahoutin-Lobozounkpa group.

loans.use: To buy hair extensions, bags, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a married man with one child who attends school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

For the past three years, he has operated a vegetable stall, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. In addition, he operates a motorcycle business that contributes to his other source of income. He faces the major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators in the market. He dreams of expanding and purchasing another motorcycle for transport in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to repair his motorcycle and purchase spare parts. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle and purchase spare parts.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man with two children, one boy and one girl. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

For the past seven years, he has operated a bakery business, selling in a shop to his neighbors and passersby. He faces the major challenge of the high cost of purchasing food products. He dreams of establishing another bakery shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase an oven for his bread baking business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase an oven to bake bread

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en: Immaculate lives in Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. Immaculate has a beauty salon. She has been in this business for eight years and she works seven days out of every week. Immaculate sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Immaculate has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cream relaxers and braids. The main business challenges for Immaculate include defaulters, the ever-increasing price of cream relaxers and braids, and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only and to educate her children up to university. Immaculate lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, braids and weaves

loans.name: Jonard

texts.en:
Jonard is 42 years of age and married with two school-aged children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines and has been doing this work for seven years now. Jonard is engaged in the business of raising livestock for fattening. 

He is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy feed for the piglets he is raising. He hopes that this loan will expand his business to further support the needs of his family, such as food. 

In the business, Jonard earns PHP 12,000 every after four months of disposing his fattened pigs. His biggest dream in life is to see his children finish their studies in college for the comfort of their future living.

loans.use: to buy feed for the piglets he is raising.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah lives in Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (in-laws). Hadjah has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for eight years and she works six days out of every week. Hadjah sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  Hadjah has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenges for Hadjah include defaulters, transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only and to educate her children up to university .Hadjah lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent and medication.

loans.use: To  buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more coffee for resale.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 33 years old and a widowed mother of two children who attend school. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last five years and employs one farmhand. Her farm is currently producing bananas and milk, which are sold at the local market. She mainly depends on her farming income to cater to the needs of her family. 

With this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she intends to employ casual laborers to help her cultivate bigger acreage of cabbages, kales and onions, which will enable her to practice horticultural farming. The proceeds from this project will help to pay school fees for her children. Her biggest challenge has been diseases, which affect her output. She plans to venture into poultry farming in the next five years.

loans.use: To employ casual laborers to help cultivate her vegetable farm.

loans.name: Baasan-Ochir

texts.en:
Baasan-Ochir, 29, lives with his 24-year-old wife and two sons who are four and two years old. They live on his father’s property in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Since 2003 he has been running a taxi service with a car he bought from a taxi company. Depending on the season, his earnings are good. It is the main source of income for this young family.

Baasan-Ochir’s car has become old and in disrepair. He needs to fix it up and make some adjustments to it. Baasan-Ochir is requesting a loan to repair his taxi and so raise his earnings. This is his second loan; the first he repaid successfully and on time.

loans.use: to repair his taxi.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 35 years old and lives in Paynesville. He is married and presently a college student while his wife is a businesswoman. The couple has two children ages four and nine, with both presently in school.

For two years now Isaac has been running a mini-filling station where he sells gasoline and fuel oil. He makes a lot of money since petroleum products have a quick turnover; he never sells less than 200 gallons a day.

Isaac is requesting a loan to purchase more drums of petroleum products for his business. He plans to open a modern filling station in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more drums of petroleum products.

loans.name: Philis

texts.en:
Philis is a resident of Nkubu in Central Kenya and works with the local Chogoria hospital as well as carrying out farming. She has been in active farming for the last 10 years with her produce of bananas, maize, beans and eggs being sold to the local market. She is married with three children. Two of the children are still in school. 

Philis has requested a loan of 55,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. This is Philis' second loan from Juhudi. Her first loan was for 35,000 KES. She says the income will help her to educate her children and expand her farming acreage, especially that of bananas.

She says pests and poor markets for the farm are the major challenges. She is happy with Juhudi loan services.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Hesbon

texts.en:
Hesbon is a married man with three children, one boy and two girls. He rents a house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

For the past year, Hesbon has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business. His customers are neighbors and passersby. The high cost of repairing his motorcycle is a major challenge for him.

Hesbon decided to join Yehu to access its loans. With a 20,000 KES loan he wants to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Abahuza Cooperative Group

texts.fr: Déo  est, né  au Rwanda.et il est membre du Cooperative de taxi moto Abahuza. Il est marié, il  a 46 ans, il a 6 enfants entre 11 ans et 20 ans . Il  a quatre ans des études primaires. C’est son troisieme cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit pour acheter un taxi moto destine au transport. Il  n’a aucune difficulté attendue de non-remboursement de son prêt. Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est d’améliore la qualité de service pour avoir un grand nombre des clients. Pour son ambition il voudrait avoir un taxi voiture et construire des maisons pour sa famille et  payer le minerval de ses enfant et  les faire soigner.
texts.en:
Déo was born in Rwanda. He is a member of the motorcycle taxi cooperative Abahuza. He is 46 years of age, married, and the father of six children aged between 11 and 20 years old. He completed four years of primary school. 

This is his third loan cycle with ACB. He will buy a motorcycle to be used for taxi transportation. There should be no difficulties in repaying the loan. 

His business growth strategy is to improve the quality of his service in order to increase his customer base. His goal is to someday have an automobile taxi, build houses for his family, and provide for his children’s tuition and healthcare.

loans.use: to buy a taxi motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Namu

texts.en: Namu is 50 years old and lives in Paynesville. She is married and her husband is an engineer. They have three children ages 9 to 25 years old and all of them are attending school. For the past five years, she has been selling cement, charcoal and drinks wholesale. Her business happens to be the only source of her income, so she is greatly praising God for this endeavor. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cement, charcoal and drinks to sell to her customers. In the future, she plans to build a bigger store with a separate division for drinks, cement and charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase more cement, charcoal and drinks to sell

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business. His potential customers are his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of competition from other motorcycle operators in his business. His major dream is to expand his business and own a permanent house in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to start a clothes-selling business and purchase second hand clothes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase second hand clothes

loans.name: Bokk Jom Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Bokk Jom est créé le 28 décembre 2010,il est composé de vingt deux femmes qui habitent le même village et qui ont comme activités principales le petit commerce et l'élevage.


Madame Fatel la responsable est âgée de 50 ans, mère de quatre enfants, elle mène un petit commerce d'arachide et fait aussi de l'embouche ovine; elle est debout à droite à l'extrême de la photo et a porté une chemise beige et un pagne à fleurettes avec un châle noir autour de la ceinture.


Elle achéte l'arachide dans les marchés hebdomadaires et revend au village.


Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des arachides et un autre mouton pour augmenter son cheptel et ainsi se faire plus tard beaucoup de revenus.


Elle compte avec ses bénéfices renforcer son épargne, participer à l'amélioration de la nourriture et la santé de sa famille.
texts.en:
Le groupe de solidarité Bokk Jom est créé le 28 décembre 2010,il est composé de vingt deux femmes qui habitent le même village et qui ont comme activités principales le petit commerce et l'élevage.


Madame Fatel la responsable est âgée de 50 ans, mère de quatre enfants, elle mène un petit commerce d'arachide et fait aussi de l'embouche ovine; elle est debout à droite à l'extrême de la photo et a porté une chemise beige et un pagne à fleurettes avec un châle noir autour de la ceinture.


Elle achéte l'arachide dans les marchés hebdomadaires et revend au village.


Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des arachides et un autre mouton pour augmenter son cheptel et ainsi se faire plus tard beaucoup de revenus.


Elle compte avec ses bénéfices renforcer son épargne, participer à l'amélioration de la nourriture et la santé de sa famille.

loans.use: ACHETER DES ARACHIDES A TRANSFORMER ET A REVENDRE.

loans.name: Dieu Est Grand Hevie Group

texts.fr: DIEU EST GRAND HEVIE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Abla Victorine (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 36 ans et est mariée à un transitaire du nom de Marc. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Abla Victorine et son mari assurent ensemble les diverses charges du ménage. Abla Victorine a très peu fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Abla Victorine mène comme activité la vente de produits divers (sucre, lait, etc.) et aussi la vente de produits vivriers (riz, maïs) à son domicile. Abla Victorine s'approvisionne au Bénin. Il y a près de cinq ans que Abla Victorine mène cette activité. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Abla Victorine sollicite un troisième crédit avec les autres membres du groupe DIEU EST GRAND HEVIE. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The "Dieu Est Grand Hevie" group comprises three people who live in the same area in Benin. The group representative, Abla Victorine (whose hand is raised in the photo) is 36 years old and married to a forwarding agent named Marc. The couple have two children, both in school and in the care of their parents. Abla Victorine and her husband together provide for the household. Abla Victorine has had very little schooling. To meet her various needs, she runs a business selling various items (sugar, milk, etc.) and also food staples (rice, maize) at her house. She gets her supplies in Benin and has run this business for close to five years. With the goal of satisfying her clientele, Abla Victorine is seeking a third loan, along with the other members of the "Dieu Est Grand Hevie" group. This loan will allow them to respond better to the demands of their customers and generate higher profits.

loans.use: To buy 2 bags of rice, 2 bags of maize, 2 boxes of sugar, and 2 cartons of milk.

loans.name: Sardar

texts.ru:
Sardar jenat uje imeyet 4 detey. Yemu 51 qod. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom pereselenec iz Kalbajar , seychas projivayet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey jenoy i detmi.
Sardar uje 18 let kak rabotayet v etom biznesse i proizvodit dveri, okna, reshotki i t.d iz dereva i jelezi. Eto uje vtoraya ssuda Sardara on ochen blagodaren za pervuyus ssudu lenderam i Kive. Ne bilo nikakix problem s yego oplatoy. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit materiali dlya izqotovleniya zakazov.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/2754
texts.en: Sardar is married and has four children.  He is 51 years old.  He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) and relocated from Kalbajar and now lives in the Absheron region together with his wife and children.  Sardar has been working in the business of making doors, windows and the like from wood and metal for eighteen years.  This is Sardar's second loan, and he is very grateful to the lenders and Kiva for that previous loan.  He had no problems repaying it.  Currently, Sardar needs 2000 AZN in order to buy materials for fulfilling his work orders.

loans.use: to purchase materials for fulfilling work orders

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 81 years old and a divorced mother of four children who are all adults. She is a farmer from eastern Kenya where she has been farming for 60 years. Her mixed farm produces potatoes, cabbages, maize and carrots, which she sells at the local market. Her major challenge in this business has been the difficulty in getting farm inputs, which affects her production.

With this loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings, she intends to purchase a dairy cow. She says that this loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk to earn her more income. The proceeds from this loan will help her improve her living standards. She plans to expand her dairy farming in the future by acquiring at least three dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Burmaa

texts.en: Mrs. Burmaa, age 57, is a woman who is trying to make repairs to her apartment because of the old and dangerous living conditions. She lives with her husband and both are retirees. This borrower has worked as an accountant in a water management company and now she receives a grant amounting to only MNT 270,474 a month. It is not enough to make repairs to her home. Therefore, she is taking a loan to purchase some building materials to repair her apartment. She says ”Thank you so much for supporting me to improve my living conditions.”

loans.use: To purchase building materials to repair her apartment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goods so as to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy hair cutting supplies and establish a barber shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and milk.

loans.name: Peang

texts.en:
Mrs. Peang, 53, and her husband, 54, are always thinking about the strategy to success in their life. To develop the family in prosperity, Mrs. Peang works as a farmer. In addition, she takes time out of her farming business to sell fish in her village and other villages. She earns $3 per day. Her husband is the director of the family. All the people know him as a construction worker in the village. He earns an income of $6 per day. To improve the family in honor, Mrs. Peang wishes to borrow some funds to support her farming business. She would like to request $1,100 to purchase land.

She appears in the photo with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase land.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina is a married woman with six children, two of whom attend school while four have graduated. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, Angelina has sold clothes to her neighbors and passersby. She also sells cereals, which contribute as another source of income.
 
Angelina decided to join Yehu to access its loans. With a 50,000 KES loan she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a married woman with one child who attends school. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past two years, Edith has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Competition from other vegetable stall operators in the market is her major challenge.

Edith decided to join Yehu to access its loans. With a 20,000 KES loan she wants to purchase a sewing machine to start a tailoring business. She dreams of establishing a good tailoring business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine to start a tailoring business.

loans.name: Mahudjlo Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUDJLO est formé de trois personnes qui vivent dans la même zone géographique et qui mènent des activités complémentaires. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Agbalè Virginie, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Agbalè Virginie est âgée de 41 ans et est mariée à un certain Etienne. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Agbalè Virginie n’a pas été scolarisée. Il y a près de cinq ans que Agbalè Virginie exerce comme activité, la vente de haricot, de farine de manioc et de l’huile végétale à son domicile ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Agbalè Virginie s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Agbalè Virginie désire renforcer son capital et rehausser le niveau de son activité. Pour ce faire, Agbalè Virginie sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUDJLO, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: The Mahudjlo group comprises three people who live in the same geographical area and run complementary businesses. The group representative, Abgalè Virginie, is the one whose hand is raised in the photo. This is the second time this group is seeking financial support from ALIDÉ in order to raise the level of their businesses. Agbalè Virginie is 41 years old and married to a man named Etienne. The couple have four children, all in school and in the care of their parents. The couple live together with their children and provide for the family together. Agbalè Virginie never attended school. For close to five years, she has run a business selling beans, manioc flour, and vegetable oil at her home; this allows her to respond to the needs of her family without too much difficulty. She gets her supplies at a market in Benin. With the hope of better responding to the needs of her clientele, Agbalè Virginie wants to strengthen her capital and raise the level of her business. To do this, she and the other members of the Mahudjlo group are seeking their second loan from ALIDÉ.

loans.use: To buy food items (beans, manioc flour, etc.).

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is a farmer from Nkubu town in eastern Kenya. She has been in the farming business for 30 years producing coffee, cabbages and milk, which she sells at the local market and through Kenya Tea Development Authority, respectively. She earns additional income from her transport business in the same town. She is 52 years old and married with four children. One of her children currently attends school. 

Charity has made a loan request of 40,000 Kenyan shillings in order to purchase a dairy cow. She says that the proceeds from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her child in college. Her biggest challenge has been the high cost of pesticides and fertilizers, which affects her production. In the future, she plans to lease more land in order to plant nappier grass and cabbage.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mahmadsobir

texts.ru: Махмадсобир проживает в районе Рудаки. Ему 34 года. Он женат. У него трое детей. Он имеет среднее образование. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам Махмадсобир зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Он разводит скот у себя дома. Дома он создал все условия для разведения скота. Кредит берет для закупа трех голов крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Mahmadsobir lives in the Rudaki district.  He is 34 years old, married and has three children.  He has a secondary education.  His wife is a homemaker.  Mahmadsobir earns his living by breeding cattle.  He breeds cattle at his home, where he created all the necessary conditions for this business.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of three cows.

loans.use: to purchase three cows

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a married woman with three children; two attend school while one is still too young. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, Aisha has sold food from her home to her neighbors and passersby. Competition from other food vendors in the area is her major challenge.

Aisha decided to join Yehu to access its loans. With a 20,000 KES loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and utensils. She dreams of establishing a restaurant in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and utensils.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items to offer for sale, such as maize, cassava, sweet potatoes, yams, Irish potatoes, pineapples, cabbage, and paw-paws

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati has operated a vegetable stall business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business, especially during the hot dry season when the availability of vegetables in supply is low compared to demand. She dreams of opening a wholesale shop in the future.

Bahati and her husband have five children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Their greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she has requested, she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, and green vegetables to offer for sale. She decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, and green vegetables to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fish, chicken, and other stock for her business

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.fr: Mariée, Adjoa est mère de 2 enfants, qui sont tous scolarisés. Elle réside en location avec son mari et ses enfants. Adjoa contribue aux différentes charges du ménage. Dotée d'une expérience d'au moins 8 ans, Adjoa commercialise des produits cosmétiques tels que les produits défrisants, les pommades pour le corps et pour les cheveux, des gels, des parfums, des savons, des lotions et autres. Sa boutique se situe à Tokpa dans une zone très favorable à son activité. Ses clients sont constitués des petits détaillants et des particuliers. La relation s'approvisionne sur place à Tokpa, le marché international du Bénin et au Togo ou au Nigeria, deux pays frontaliers au Bénin. Face à la demande croissante de sa clientèle, elle a décidé d'entrer en partenaria avec FINADEV où elle obtint un concours financier afin de mieux achalander sa boutique. Adjoa compte sur le revenu supplémentaire à dégager de ce crédit pour faire face à ses responsabilités familiales et résoudre ses besoins personnels. Adjoa diversifier son activité afin de faire face convenablement à la concurrence.
texts.en:
A married woman, Adjoa is the mother of two children who are both in school. She rents a place with her husband and children. She helps with the various household expenses. Priviledged with at least eight years of experience, Adjoa sells cosmetics, such as straighteners, body and hair ointments, gels, perfumes, soaps, lotions, and more. Her store is located at Tokpa in a very favorable area for her business. Her customer base is composed of small-scale retailers and individuals. 

Our client is supplied locally from Tokpa, the international market of Benin, and from Togo or Nigeria, two countries bordering Benin. Facing the growing demand from her customers, she decided to enter into partnership with FINADEV, where she obtained financial aid for increasing store traffic. Adjoa is counting on the extra revenues to clear this loan in order to cope with her family responsibilities and to resolve her personal needs. She is diversifying her business to face the competition in a suitable manner.

loans.use: to buy 10 boxes ointments, 5 boxes of straightener, 5 boxes of perfumes, and 5 boxes of soaps

loans.name: Doudedji Group

texts.fr: Le groupe DOUDEDJI est formé de trois personnes qui habitent toutes ensemble dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Lucienne est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Lucienne est âgée de 52 ans et vit au Bénin. Lucienne est mariée à un cuisinier du nom de Bernard et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à sa charge. Lucienne vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Il y a juste un an que Lucienne a commencé la vente d'ustensiles en plastiques, de chaussures et des friperies de façon secondaire ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille et de subvenir à ses besoins. Lucienne s’approvisionne au Bénin. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Lucienne désire augmenter le stock de ses produits. Pour ce faire, Lucienne sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe DOUDEDJI, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: The Doudedji group comprises three people who live together in the same area. The group representative, named Lucienne, is the one whose hand is raised in the photo. This is the second time this group is seeking financial support from ALIDÉ in order to raise the level of their businesses. Lucienne is 52 years old and lives in Benin. She is married to a cook named Bernard and has two children, both in school and in her care. Lucienne lives together with her husband and children. Just about a year ago, Lucienne began selling plastic kitchenware, shoes, and second-hand clothing on the side; this allows her to respond to her needs and those of her family without too much difficulty. She gets her supplies in Benin. With the goal of better responding to the demands of her clientele, Lucienne wants to increase her stock of products. To do this, she and the other members of the Doudedji group are seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ.

loans.use: To buy plastic kitchenware and bales of second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma operates a restaurant business, serving his neighbors and passers-by. He has been engaged in this business for the past five years. He faces a major challenge of competition in his business. He dreams of becoming financially independent in the future. 

Juma and his wife have seven children, two of whom are grown and five of whom attend school. The family lives in a rented house that has electricity but not piped water. Juma's greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan he has requested, he wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, rice, beans, and cooking fat oil. He decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, rice, beans and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar, rice, beans, and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Mwanamkuu

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu is a vendor of cashew nuts, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. She has been engaged in her business for the past ten years. The seasonality of cashew nuts is the primary challenge she faces in her business. She dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier of cashew nuts.
 
Mwanamkuu is a divorced woman with two children who have already graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she has requested, she wants to purchase three bales of cashew nuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase three bales of cashew nuts to offer for sale

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie est âgée de 31 ans et est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Nestor. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Marie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la maison sont assurées par le couple. Marie n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Marie prépare de la nourriture (pâte de maïs accompagné de sauce, bouillie d'amidon de maïs, etc.) qu’elle vend dans une ville du Bénin. Marie s’approvisionne dans l’un des marchés du Bénin. Dans le but de rehausser son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Marie sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième prêt. Les deux premiers crédits ont été tous bien remboursés.
texts.en: Marie is 31 years old and married to a driver named Nestor. The couple have three children, all in school and in their care. Marie lives together with her husband and children. The various household expenses are taken care of by the couple together. Marie did not attend school. To provide for herself and her children, she prepares meals (maize paste with sauce, cornstarch-based 'bouillie', etc.) that she sells in a city in Benin. Marie gets her supplies at one of the markets in Benin. With the goal of expanding her business and better responding to the demands of her clientele, Marie is seeking her third loan through ALIDÉ. The two previous loans were both repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy maize, condiments, sugar, and milk.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey has operated a matatu (motor vehicle) business for the past five years. His potential customers are passers-by and travelers. He faces a major challenge in the high costs of servicing his vehicle. Geoffrey dreams of purchasing another motor vehicle in the future.
 
Geoffrey and his wife have one child who is still too young for school. The family lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Geoffrey's greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan he has requested, Geoffrey plans to purchase construction materials, sand, and cement. He decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials, sand, and cement

loans.name: Gilberte

texts.fr: Gilberte est mariée et vit en location avec ses 2 enfants qui vont tous à l'école et qui évoluent très bien dans leur études. Le couple s’associe pour faire face aux dépenses du ménage. Gilberte, commerçante mène son activité depuis 5 ans et y a une notoriété. Elle a pour principale activité la vente de divers articles d'habillement tels que les colliers en perles, les chaussures, les prêt-à-porter, les objets de décoration et autres. Elle effectue ses achats en fonction du chiffre d'affaire réalisé et des besoins de ses clients sur place à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin et au Togo, un pays frontalier au Bénin. La cliente fabrique elle-même les perles. Pour y parvenir, elle achète les matières premières de base et dispose de quelques outils qui l'aide dans la confection. Gilberte a une variété de clientèle constituée des habitants de sa zone commerciale et de ses environs. La sollicitation de plus en plus croissante de sa clientèle l'oblige à faire recours au micro crédit que FINADEV lui accorde afin de l'aider à développer son activité et à maximiser son bénéfice. Avec ce bénéfice, pourra faire face aux besoins financiers de la famille. Elle souhaiterait que son activité évolue afin de lui permettre de faire voyager ses enfants dans le cadre de leurs études.
texts.en:
Gilberte is a married woman and rents a place with her two children, who go to school and are doing well in their studies. The couple are together in coping with household expenses. Gilberte is a merchant and has been in this business for five years and has a certain amount of fame. She mainly sells various items of dress, such as bead necklaces, footwear, ready-to-wear, decorative objects, and more. She makes her purchases according to her actual turnover rate and the needs of her local customer base at Tokpa, the largest market in Benin, and in Togo, a country bordering Benin. 

Our client makes the beads herself. To do so, she buys the raw materials and makes use of a few tools that help her make them. She has a variety of customers made up of people who live in her commercial district and nearby. 

The burgeoning requests from her customers compels her to turn toward the micro-financing that FINADEV grants her in order to develop her business and to maximize her profits. With this loan, Gilberte will be able to cope with the financial needs of her family. She would like her business to progress, so as to allow her to send her children abroad for school.

loans.use: to buy 2 dozen shoes, 5 beaded bags, and 20 ready-to-wear outfits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase one box of books to offer for sale

loans.name: Tobias

texts.en:
Tobias has operated a block selling business for the past five years, selling to contractors and house builders. He faces a major challenge of competition from other block supplies in the market. He dreams of improving his livelihood in the future.
 
Tobias and his wife live in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase coral blocks to offer for sale. He decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase coral blocks to offer for sale

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan, age 54, operates a clothes sales business in his town. He started this business in 2005. In addition, he runs a business trading plastic bowls and bottles. He collects used cans and bottles in bulk. He plans to obtain a large storage facility where he can load and store large quantities of cans and bottles. 

He is a diligent man who is planning to expand his business in the future. He says, "Because of insufficient collateral, I am having difficulty receiving loans from banks." He is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase more bottles and to increase his working capital.

Jargalsaihan lives with his wife in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian yurt, in the Govisumber province of Mongolia. His wife is an inspector who works at a public organization. All of their children are grown and live separately.

loans.use: to purchase more bottles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more foods such as maize, cassava, rice, and coffee to offer for sale

loans.name: Jamsran

texts.en:
Jamsran is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a house in Suhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His older two children, aged 10 and 12, attend secondary school while the youngest one who hasn't reached school age stays home. 

Jamsran manages a cell phone repair and sales business at a rented stall at a trading center. He started his business in 1996 after his graduation as a cell phone repairman. Since then his business has been quite successful which allowed him to rent a stall in 2009. He is planning to expand and continue his business in the future. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts to repair cellphones.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for cellphones.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 53 years old and a married mother of three children who are all adults. She has been practicing mixed farming for 30 years now, producing milk, cabbages and tea, which she sells both locally and through Kenya Tea Development Authority, respectively. She is also employed by the Postal Corporation Company in Kenya.

With this loan of 47,250 Kenyan Shillings, she intends to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her young daughter who is in college. She faces the challenges of diseases and lack of enough farm inputs like fertilizers, which affects her production. In the future, she plans to expand her dairy farm and plant more nappier grass for her cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock (Soap,Tissue, Toothpaste, etc) for her business.

loans.name: Jerusha

texts.en:
Jerusha is a farmer from Nkubu town in eastern Kenya. She has been in the farming business for 20 years and employs one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces milk, french beans, potatoes, cabbages and eggs which are all sold to the local market. Farming has been her main source of income. She is 51 and married with four children, one of whom is currently attending school.

With this loan of 45,900 Kenyan shillings, she intends to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income that will be generated from the sale of milk will go towards paying school fees and opening a small kiosk in her location. Her biggest challenges have been pests and diseases and insufficient water for irrigation. She hopes that in the next five years, she will have bought a chaff (hay) cutter and a pick-up truck for transporting her farm produce.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nonviwowo Group

texts.fr: NONVIWOWO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, YVETTE (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 26 ans et est mariée à un pâtissier du nom de Ekoué. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. YVETTE et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges des enfants. YVETTE n'a été à l'école.  Il y a près de quatre ans que YVETTE mène comme activité la vente de produits divers (farine de blé, sels, sucre) de façon ambulante. YVETTE exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. YVETTE s’approvisionne au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, YVETTE sollicite un premier crédit avec les membres du groupe NONVIWOWO. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
NONVIWOWO is a group composed of three persons whose members reside in the same district of Benin. The group’s representative, YVETTE (whose hand is raised in the photo) is 26 years old and married to a baker by the name of Ekoué. This couple has four children to support; three of  are their own; some of them have had schooling. YVETTE and her husband live together with their children and jointly ensure that the various family expenses are covered. 

For nearly four years, YVETTE has been running a business selling a variety goods (wheat flour, salt, sugar) door to door. She operates this business with passion, and it enables her to meet her needs and those of her children. She gets her supplies from Benin. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers, she and the other members of the group NONVIWOWO are requesting an initial loan. They will use this loan to respond better to customer demands and to make more profit.

loans.use: to buy sacks of wheat flour, sugar, and table salt

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a cow for the butcher shop.

loans.name: Agneta

texts.en:
Agnetta is a married woman with four children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a butterflies-hunting business, selling to foreigners visiting the coastal region. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, during hot dry season the availability of butterflies is lower compared to demand. She dreams of supplying as wholesale in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase equipment for hunting butterflies for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for hunting butterflies for sale.

loans.name: Kamengele

texts.en:
Kamengele is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past 20 years, she has operated a farming business, planting maize and beans for sale. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a grocery business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes and onions for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes and onions for sale.

loans.name: Kabende United Group

texts.en: Abbas is 27 years old, and is married with two children. His family lives in a semi-permanet house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to build a permanent house for his family. Abbas sells both new and second-hand clothes at the surrounding markets in the area. The major challenge he faces in his business is high transportation costs and for that reason his dream is to set up a boutique. Abbas needs a loan to buy clothes for resale. He is a member of the Kabende United Group and as a policy every member guarantees the other in acquiring a loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Gbediga Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GBEDIGA est formé de trois personnes qui vivent dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Ayaba Aubierge, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Ayaba Aubierge est âgée de 28 ans et est mariée à un enseignant du nom de Marius. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont les leurs. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Ayaba Aubierge n’a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a près de quatre ans que Ayaba Aubierge exerce comme activité, la vente de mèches tissage, des savons et des produits de toilettes, par le système de distribution ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Ayaba Aubierge s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Ayaba Aubierge désire renforcer son capital et rehausser le niveau de son activité. Pour ce faire, Ayaba Aubierge sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBEDIGA, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
GBEDIGA is a group formed of three persons who live in the same district in Benin. The group’s representative, named Ayaba Aubierge, is the one with her hand raised in the photo. This is the first time that this group has requested financial support from ALIDé with the aim of boosting their business. Ayaba Aubierge is 28 years old and married to a teacher by the name of Marius. They support three children, of whom two are their own. All of the children are in school. This couple lives together with their children and jointly covers the various need of the family. 

Ayaba Aubierge attended primary school only.  For nearly four years, she has had a business selling hair extensions, weaves, soaps, and personal care products, via the distribution system. This enables her to respond to family needs without much trouble. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

Concerned about responding to the requirements of her customers, she would like to bolster her capital and raise her level of business. To do so, she and the other member of the group GBEDIGA are requesting an initial loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy 2 boxes of soap, 6 dozen weaves, and some personal care products

loans.name: Nyakitokoli Karangura Group

texts.en:
Annet, age 26, is a fish vendor. She has been engaged in her business for the past two years. Her major challenges are unsettled debts from customers and fish going bad due to lack of refrigeration facilities.

Annet needs this loan to buy fish to offer for sale. Her dream is to expand her business.

Annet's husband is a famer, and they help each other take care of the family. They have three children and live in Fort Portal, Uganda. Their dream is to ensure the education of their children.

loans.use: to buy fish to offer for sale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. Her major dream is to establish a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose has been in the farming business for two years, producing cabbages and onions which she sells to the local market. She is also a beautician and owns a salon in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya. She is aged 25 and married with two children who both attend school. 

Rose has made a loan request of 30,000 Kenyan shillings in order to buy chickens and chicken feed. She hopes that by venturing into poultry farming, her income will be increased and this will help her pay school fees for her children. She faces the challenge of high cost of farm inputs especially fertilizers which affects her production. In future, she plans to lease more land for planting cabbages and also practice large-scale poultry farming.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a married man with eleven children; four children attend school while seven have graduated from school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling from door to door to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality especially during the cold rainy season when the availability of customers is low. 

With the Kshs 10,000 he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Osman

texts.en:
Osman is 35 years old and married with four children, aged between 7 and 18. He runs a General Merchandise store in Lumley, a neighborhood in Freetown. He also has four relatives to take care of as well as his immediate family.   

Osman has owned this business for five years and sells rice, flour, sugar and oil at his store. He also earns income from renting a house out to tenants. He says that the main challenge to his business is that during the rainy season business is relatively slow. 

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more rice, sugar and flour. Osman says that the extra income from this loan will help him improve the standard of living of his family. In the future, he would like to import goods from overseas.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, sugar and flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock for her cosmetics sales business.

loans.name: Yeyinou Group

texts.fr: YEYINOU est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Christiane(dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 49 ans et est mariée à un professeur du nom de Rémi. Le couple a cinq enfants à charge, tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont les leurs. Christiane et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges des enfants. Christiane a arrêté l’école au cours primaire. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Christiane vend de l'igname frit accompagné de beignets de haricot à son domicile. Christiane s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Christiane exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Christiane sollicite un premier crédit avec les membres du groupe YEYINOU. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: YEYINOU is a group of three persons whose members reside in the same district in Benin. The group’s representative, Christiane (with her hand raised in the photo) is 49 years old and married to a teacher by the name of Rémi. They support five children, all in school. Four of the children are their own. Christiane and her husband live together with their children and jointly ensure that the various family expenses are covered. Christiane dropped out primary school. To cope with her different expenses, she sells fried yams served with bean beignets out of her home. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. She operates this business with passion. It enables her to provide for herself and her children. Seeking to satisfy her customers, she and the other members of the group YEYINOU are requesting an initial loan. This loan will serve to respond better to customer demands and to make more profit.

loans.use: to buy sacks of yams and beans

loans.name: Siyanqoba Group

texts.en:
Lungile is 27 years old and single with 2 children, ages 4 and 7. She also takes care of many relatives who live with her. For the last two years, she has been operating a small retail business selling bread, cold drinks, and airtime from her home in Empangeni, South Africa. She also receives a grant from the South African government to support her children.

Lungile requested a loan from WDB and Kiva to add to her stock of airtime and cold drinks. Eventually, she would like to use the earnings from her business to purchase a car, which will greatly help her business expand even further. She says that the biggest challenge her business faces is that customers take her stock on credit but do not repay her on time. She says that WDB and Kiva have helped improve her life greatly by helping her business.

loans.use: to buy airtime and cold drinks for resale

loans.name: Musu

texts.en: Musu is 47 years old and lives in Paynesville. She attended school, attaining 11th grade. She is married and her husband is a teacher. They have four children two of whom live at home and attend school. Musu sells dried goods, mainly foodstuffs and charcoal, from a table in the market. Her main difficulty is keeping the business going when school fees and other expenses use up all her cash. She learnt this business from her mother and is proud to run her own business. She’s requesting a loan to ensure that she always has stock for her business. In the future, she wants to complete the children’s education and buy them a house.

loans.use: to ensure that she always has stock for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil, bread and so on for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Charity Group

texts.en:
Bonhiwe is 28 years old and single with two children who both attend school. She also cares for many relatives that live with her. For the last five years, she has been operating a food stall from her home in Empangeni, South Africa. She sells cakes, chips, and sausages to her neighbors. She also receives money from the South African government to support her children.

Bonhiwe requested a loan through WDB and Kiva to buy ingredients that she will use to make food. Eventually, she would like to open a shelter away from her home to sell her food. Her business has been growing, which has helped her send her children to school. She says that WDB and Kiva have helped her by lending money, and she sees her life improving greatly. In the photo, she is pictured raising her hand.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for making food to sell

loans.name: Kasusu Twekambe Group

texts.en:
Teddy is a 39-year-old married woman with eight children, all living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She takes care of the family, and her dream is to educate her children and build a commercial house.

For six years she has been operating a bar and she got her initial capital from selling fresh food. Her major challenge now is inadequate capital to meet the demand.

Teddy needs the loan to buy crates of beer and local gin for resale.

loans.use: To buy crates of beer and local gin for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her range of products

loans.name: Kiraaro Twekambe Group

texts.en:
Peter is a 59-year-old married man with 12 children living in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to own a market stall in the central market of Fort Portal town.

He has been a tomato vendor for the last 15 years and the major hardship faced is price fluctuations for tomatoes. Peter needs the loan to buy tomatoes to sell.

loans.use: To buy a tomato garden.

loans.name: Sabathwa Group

texts.en:
Ntombiyesipho is 56 years old and married with 4 children between 18 and 31 years old. She also takes care of 2 relatives who live with her. For the last three years, she has been raising chickens and selling them from her home in Empangeni, South Africa. She also receives a pension from the South African government.

Ntombiyesipho requested a loan from WDB and Kiva to buy chicks and feed to help grow her stock. She says that the biggest challenge she faces is that her livestock has been dying, robbing her of the efforts and capital she invested in them. With this loan, she will be able to make money and send it to her children who are not living with her anymore. She would like to thank WDB and Kiva for extending this loan to her. In the photo she is raising her hand.

loans.use: to buy baby chickens and feed

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is a 47-year-old Rwanda entrepreneur who is married with four children between the ages of 10 and 22. All of her children are in school and she and her husband are both farmers. 

Vestine has worked as a farmer for the past 5 years and sells foodstuffs.She requires a loan in order to purchase a milling machine. This machine will help her generate enough profits so that she can begin constructing a family house.

loans.use: to buy a milling machine.

loans.name: Jean Batiste

texts.en:
Jean Batiste is a 23-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. He is not married and for the past six years has been running a general store selling sugar, cooking oil, rice, and other goods.  

His business is going well, and he requires a loan so that he can purchase more goods that will allow him to continue to expand his business and grow his profits.

His goal in the future is to generate enough income so that he can begin construction of a house

loans.use: to buy goods such as cooking oil, rice, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more land to expand his tea farm.

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
Rosaline is 50 years old and married with three children between the ages 17 and 23. She runs a plumbing materials store in Krootown inside Freetown. She also takes care of four relatives as well as their own family.

Rosaline has owned this business for 10 years and sells pipes, seat covers, cement and cables at her store. She also receives income from renting out a house to a tenant. She says that the main challenge to her business is customers always return damaged items after they pay for the product.  

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more plumbing materials. Rosaline says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her business and increase her savings. In the future, she would like to expand her business more.

loans.use: To purchase more plumbing materials, pipes and cement for resale.

loans.name: Siyabonna Group

texts.en:
Rebecca is 45 years old and single with four children, between 14 and 27 years old. Three of her children attend school. For the last two years, she has been operating a retail store near the pension pay point in Empangeni, South Africa, selling tupperware, perfume and clothes. She also receives a grant from the South African government to support her children.

Rebecca requested a loan from WDB and Kiva to purchase clothes to increase the selection she offers at her store. Her business has been growing, and she is now able to afford a house with furniture. Rebecca said that the support she received from WDB has greatly improved her life. In the photo she is pictured raising her hand.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Tecla

texts.en: Tecla is a mother of three and has been in farming for five years, producing milk and eggs which are sold to the local market in her home town of Eldoret in Kenya. Tecla has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry and expand her poultry unit. She says the loan will definitely improve her family's living standard and she aspires to grow her farm to a large-scale one. She laments the high costs associated with poultry diseases and adds that Juhudi loans have gone a long way in helping needy farmers.

loans.use: To buy more poutry and expand poultry unit

loans.name: Gaudance

texts.en:
Gaudance is a 32-year-old Rwanda entrepreneur with four children between the ages of 3 and 11, all of whom are in school.  Her husband works in a hospital.

For the past 11 years, she has owned a pharmacy selling drugs, and this business has helped her meet the needs of her family.

She requires this loan in order to purchase a variety of drugs that she will sell in her pharmacy  and so that she can continue to generate profits that provide for the well-being of her family.

loans.use: to buy pharmaceuticals for sale.

loans.name: Vukanathi Group

texts.en:
Alice is 51 years old and single with three children. She also takes care of two relatives who live with her. For the last two years, she has operated a small store from her home. She sells chickens, bags, and perfumes to her neighbors. She also receives a grant from the South African government to help support her children.

Alice requested a loan from WDB and Kiva to buy more perfume and bags for resale. Her business has been growing, but she says that the biggest challenge she faces is that her customers take her stock on credit and do not repay her on time. Her life will be greatly improved by this loan. She would like to thank WDB and Kiva for the support. In the photo she is raising her hand.

loans.use: to purchase bags and perfumes to resell.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix is a 24-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur.  He is not married and for the past five years has owned a general store selling rice, sugar, cooking oil, etc.

He will use this loan to purchase more goods to sell in his store so he can continue to generate more profits.  In the future, he plans to build a house for himself and dreams of having a larger store.

loans.use: to buy goods for sale such as cooking oil, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is 31 years old and married with one child aged 15. She runs a body cream store (cosmetics) in Tengbehtown inside Freetown. She also takes care of two relatives as well as their own family.

Mariama has owned this business for five years and sells body creams, hair products and pink oil lotion at her store. She also earns income from transportation (bike).  She says that her business is doing well.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more body creams and hair products.    Mariama says that the extra income from this loan will help her to educate her child and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to buy goods from neighboring countries.

loans.use: To purchases more body creams, hair products and hair creams.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more foods such as bananas, cassava, yams and beans to resell.

loans.name: Josepha

texts.en:
Josepha is a 28-year-old, married Rwandan entrepreneur. She has 3 children, who are between the ages of 4 and 8. All of her children are in school, while she and her husband run a business together. 

For the past 4 years, she has operated a general store, where she sells soaps, beans, salt, and other goods. The profits from the business have helped her meet the needs of her family. 

She is seeking this loan so that she can purchase a variety of goods that she will then sell in her store. She expects that the loan proceeds will allow her to generate additional profits, which she will use to support her family.  She also plans to save any future profits she earns to ensure the well-being of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods (e.g., soaps, beans, and salt) for re-sale purposes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional coffee for re-sale purposes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional animals.

loans.name: G.s. Chavarria Group

texts.es: El Grupo solidario Chavarría lo conforman Paula Emilia y Juana Del Carmen. Paula se dedica a la venta de refrescos, tiene más de 21 años de dedicarse a este medio de vida. La ubicación es en la terminal de buses en donde diariamente transitan alrededor de 50 a 100 personas lo que le resulta muy favorable. Juana tiene su pulpería, hace mas de 16 años que tiene este negocio con el paso del tiempo ha logrado incrementar a la mayoría de sus clientes pues conocen muy bien los productos que ofrece. El crédito es para la compra de galletas, golosinas un poco de cosméticos, pan y otros productos.
texts.en:
The C. solidarity group is made up of Paula Emilia and Juana Del Carmen. Paula sells drinks, and has made her living doing this for 21 years. She sells in the bus station where approximately 50 to 100 people pass by every day; this is very profitable. 
Juana has a general store, and has had this business for over 16 years. With the passing of time, her store has grown. The majority of her customers know her products very well. This loan is for the purchase of cookies, sweets, some cosmetics, bread, and other products.

loans.use: to purchase cookies, candies, some cosmetics, bread, and other products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional omena fish, repair her boat, and buy a fishing net.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her inventory by purchasing chairs, sugar, salad, and flour.

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice is 39 years old. He is married to three wives, Beatrice, Seline and Eunice, and they have seven children.

He is a fishmonger and has been in business for the last fifteen years. He is applying for KES. 75,000 to enable him to buy another boat and fishing net to enable him to do his business well.

The profits made will help him take care of his three families well and enable him to pay school fees for his children. He hopes to have a big supply of fish in the area.

loans.use: To buy a boat and a fishing net.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a fishing net and a boat.

loans.name: Las Reinas Fortaleza Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LAS REYNAS FORTALEZA” iniciará su segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Los Andes, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Rufina quien en la fotrografia es la que tiene lentes. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: carpintería, kiosco de salchipapas, kiosco de dulces y venta de comida, venta de habas y chicharrones, costura de bolsas, tienda de dulces, producción de mochilas, producción de mantas.

La señora Rufina,  indica que es la primera vez que trabaja con Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de una promotora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de  venta de material de librería que inicio desde hace doce años. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para la incrementar su capital (compra de cuadernos, hojas y lápices) que comprará por mayor de la Ceja y 16 de Julio y que posteriormente lo venderá en su domicilio. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta salud.

En la fotografia falta la señora Wilma porque estuvo en consulta en el área de salud.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Las Reynas Fortalieza” (The Queens of Fortitutde) is starting its second loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Los Andes Community Center. The group consists of nine members and is lead by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Rufina, who is the woman in the photograph wearing glasses. The members of the Communal Bank engage in various businesses to get ahead such as carpentry, running a “salchipapas” (sausages and potatoes) kiosk, running a candy kiosk, selling food, selling beans and pork, sewing handbags, selling sweets, producing backpacks, and producing blankets.

Sra. Rufina says this is the first time she has worked with Pro Mujer. She joined the organization after being invited by a promoter. She currently manages a bookstore that she started 12 years ago.

Her loan will be used to increase her capital for buying notebooks, sheets of paper, and pencils. She buys in bulk in the neighborhoods of La Ceja and July 16th and then sells her merchandise at home. Working in this manner allows her to generate income to support her family. Rufina is married and has two children. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Rufina said she enjoys the health services.

Sra. Wilma does not appear in the photograph because she was at the health clinic.

loans.use: to purchase notebooks, sheets of paper, and pencils.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 35 years old and married with four children, aged between 3 and 20. She runs a provisions and assorted drinks store in Lumley in the neighborhood of Freetown.

Fatmata has been in this business for six years and sells milk, biscuits and soft drinks at her store. She  owns a taxi from which she also earns income.

She says that her business is doing well. She also takes care of two of her relatives as well as their families.  Of her children, three are currently in secondary school and another in university. 

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more provisions and assorted drinks. Fatmata says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her savings and educate her children. In the future, she would like to open a supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase more milk, biscuits and soft drinks.

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is a 31-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur with three children between the ages of 4 and 10.  The two elder children are in school, and he and his wife run a business together selling used clothes. 

He has been running this business with his wife for the past 3 years, and the profits generated from this business have enabled him to pay the school fees for his children.

He will use this loan to purchase more used clothes that he will sell in order to generate profits. 

He hopes to earn enough future profits so that he can renovate his house. As a business man, he aspires to become a clothes wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Mriphe

texts.en:
Mriphe is a married man with four children; three attend school while one is underage. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
